title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
subtitle: What AI is, where it fits, and why it matters.
content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the field of building systems that can perceive, reason, learn, and act. It spans rule-based systems, statistical learning, and modern deep learning. The goal is not just automation, but decision-making that improves with data.

sections.title: Why AI now?
sections.content: AI adoption is accelerating due to better data pipelines, cheaper compute, and stronger algorithms. Businesses use AI to personalize experiences, automate workflows, and improve decision quality.

sections.title: Where AI shows up
sections.content: AI powers recommendations, fraud detection, language translation, medical imaging, code assistants, and smart devices. Understanding the basics helps you evaluate real-world systems responsibly.

tabs.title: Core Concepts
tabs.description: AI involves perception (input), reasoning (decisions), and learning (improving over time). It uses data and algorithms to solve problems that are hard to capture with fixed rules.
bullets: General AI is a long-term research goal
Learning can be supervised, unsupervised, or reinforcement-based
tabs.imageAlt: Abstract technology network with glowing nodes

tabs.title: AI Lifecycle
tabs.description: Successful AI products move from data collection to training, evaluation, deployment, and monitoring. Each step reduces risk and improves reliability.
bullets: Define the business problem and success metrics
Collect, clean, and label the right data
Monitor drift and feedback loops after launch

tabs.title: Real-World Impact
tabs.description: AI changes how people work. It can improve productivity but also introduces fairness and privacy concerns that must be addressed early.
bullets: Use AI to augment, not replace, human judgment
Audit for bias and test across user groups
Document data sources and model limitations

resources.title: What is Artificial Intelligence?
resources.description: A clear introduction to AI definitions, history, and examples.

resources.title: AI vs ML vs DL
resources.description: Understand how AI relates to machine learning and deep learning.

title: AI Ethics and Bias
subtitle: Designing AI systems that are fair, transparent, and safe.
content: Ethical AI focuses on fairness, accountability, privacy, and transparency. Bias can enter from data, modeling decisions, or deployment context, so review each stage carefully.

tabs.title: Common Risks
tabs.description: AI can amplify historical bias, over-collect data, or automate harmful decisions. Managing risk means proactive analysis and continuous oversight.
tabs.imageAlt: Code and UI on a laptop

tabs.title: Best Practices
tabs.description: Build guardrails early. Use fairness checks, human-in-the-loop reviews, and model cards to document behavior.
bullets: Audit data for imbalance and outliers
Set monitoring alerts for harmful outputs

tabs.title: Governance
tabs.description: Policies, reviews, and documentation keep AI aligned with user trust and regulatory requirements.

resources.title: Fairness in Machine Learning
resources.description: Overview of bias sources and mitigation techniques.

title: Model Evaluation Metrics
subtitle: Measure model quality with the right metrics.
content: Choosing the right metric is essential. Accuracy alone can be misleading, especially with imbalanced data. Use precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC to understand real performance.

sections.title: Classification metrics
sections.content: Precision focuses on correctness of positive predictions, while recall focuses on capturing actual positives. F1 balances both when trade-offs matter.

sections.title: Regression metrics
sections.content: MAE, MSE, and RMSE show average error magnitude. R2 explains how much variance the model captures.

tabs.title: Confusion Matrix
tabs.description: The confusion matrix breaks predictions into true positives, false positives, true negatives, and false negatives. It is the foundation for most classification metrics.
bullets: High false positives can hurt trust
High false negatives can miss critical cases

tabs.title: Imbalanced Data
tabs.description: For rare events, accuracy can be high even when the model is wrong most of the time. Precision, recall, and PR curves are better choices.

tabs.title: Threshold Tuning
tabs.description: Many models output probabilities. Adjust the threshold to meet business constraints, such as safety or fraud detection targets.

resources.title: Precision and Recall in ML
resources.description: Detailed explanation with examples.

resources.title: Confusion Matrix
resources.description: How to build and interpret confusion matrices.

title: Embeddings and Semantic Search
subtitle: Turn language into vectors that capture meaning.
content: Embeddings map text into numeric vectors that preserve semantic meaning. Similar ideas and words end up close in vector space, enabling search, clustering, and recommendation.

sections.title: Why embeddings matter
sections.content: Keyword search misses context. Embeddings allow similarity search that captures intent, not just exact words.

tabs.title: Concept
tabs.description: Embeddings represent text, images, or users as vectors. Distances in this space reflect similarity, making them essential for retrieval and recommendation.
bullets: Works across text, audio, and images

tabs.title: Workflow
tabs.description: Create embeddings, store them in a vector database, and query using similarity. Retrieval can be combined with re-ranking for better results.

tabs.title: Use Cases
tabs.description: Embeddings power semantic search, recommendations, and content clustering. They are also used in RAG pipelines for LLMs.

resources.title: Word Embedding
resources.description: Intro to embedding concepts and applications.

resources.title: NLP Introduction
resources.description: Fundamentals of NLP tasks and techniques.

title: Neural Networks
subtitle: Understand perceptrons, layers, and activation functions.
content: Neural networks are layers of interconnected nodes that learn patterns from data. Each layer transforms inputs using weights, biases, and nonlinear activation functions.

tabs.title: Building Blocks
tabs.description: A neuron computes a weighted sum and applies an activation function. Stacking neurons creates expressive models.

tabs.title: Training Loop
tabs.description: Training uses forward pass, loss calculation, backpropagation, and optimization. Iterations update weights to reduce error.

tabs.title: Activation Functions
tabs.description: ReLU is common for hidden layers. Sigmoid and softmax are used for probabilities. Choose activations based on the task.

resources.title: Artificial Neural Networks
resources.description: Key concepts and learning workflow.

title: Convolutional Neural Networks
subtitle: How CNNs learn spatial patterns in images.
content: CNNs use convolution filters and pooling layers to learn hierarchical visual features. They excel at image classification, detection, and segmentation tasks.

tabs.title: Filters
tabs.description: Filters slide across the image to detect edges, textures, and shapes. Deeper layers detect more complex features.

tabs.title: Pooling
tabs.description: Pooling reduces spatial size and adds translation invariance. Max pooling is the most common choice.

tabs.title: Applications
tabs.description: CNNs are used in medical imaging, autonomous vehicles, and quality control. Their feature hierarchy makes them robust for visual tasks.

resources.title: CNN Basics
resources.description: A quick primer on CNNs and their architecture.

title: Prompt Engineering
subtitle: Craft prompts that reliably steer LLM outputs.
content: Prompt engineering is the practice of framing instructions so that models respond accurately. It mixes clear task statements, examples, and constraints.

tabs.title: Structure
tabs.description: Use role, goal, and constraints. Provide the format you want in the output.

tabs.title: Few-Shot Examples
tabs.description: Provide a small set of examples to lock in the style and structure you want the model to follow.
bullets: Keep examples close to the task

tabs.title: Evaluate
tabs.description: Measure reliability across edge cases. Capture failures and iterate on prompts rather than guessing.

resources.title: Generative AI Overview
resources.description: Foundations of generative models and use cases.

title: AI Basics Track
subtitle: Start with foundational AI concepts, history, and ethics.
content: This track establishes a solid AI foundation. You will learn core terminology, understand how AI differs from ML and DL, and explore real-world applications with ethical context.

tabs.title: Learning Map
tabs.description: Begin with definitions and history, move into AI vs ML vs DL, then cover ethics and common applications.

tabs.title: Outcomes
tabs.description: By the end, you will recognize AI use cases, evaluate trade-offs, and communicate AI concepts clearly.

resources.title: What is Artificial Intelligence?
resources.description: A broad overview of AI concepts.

title: Machine Learning Track
subtitle: Learn supervised and unsupervised learning fundamentals.
content: Machine learning focuses on training models to learn from data. This track covers regression, classification, clustering, and evaluation basics with practical examples.

tabs.title: Core Methods
tabs.description: Master the most common algorithms and the problems they solve.

tabs.title: Practice
tabs.description: Use datasets to build intuition. Start with small datasets, then expand.

resources.title: Machine Learning Basics
resources.description: Overview of ML definitions and workflows.

title: Deep Learning Track
subtitle: Understand neural networks and modern architectures.
content: Deep learning uses multi-layer neural networks to model complex patterns. This track covers activation functions, backpropagation, CNNs, and transformers.

tabs.title: Core Concepts
tabs.description: Learn how deep networks learn representations from data.

tabs.title: Architectures
tabs.description: CNNs handle images, RNNs model sequences, and transformers power LLMs.

resources.title: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
resources.description: Intro to deep learning fundamentals.

title: NLP Track
subtitle: Learn how machines process and generate language.
content: Natural language processing turns text into structured data and meaning. This track covers preprocessing, embeddings, transformers, and language models.

tabs.title: Workflow
tabs.description: Move from raw text to embeddings and downstream tasks like classification and summarization.

tabs.title: Language Models
tabs.description: Transformers learn context across sequences and enable large language models for generation.

resources.title: NLP Introduction
resources.description: Start with NLP foundations.

title: Generative AI Track
subtitle: Create text, images, and code with modern models.
content: Generative AI focuses on models that create new content. This track explores LLM fundamentals, prompting, and safe deployment practices.

tabs.title: Core Ideas
tabs.description: Understand how generative models learn patterns and sample new outputs.

tabs.title: Use Cases
tabs.description: Generative AI supports chatbots, copilots, summarization, and creative workflows.

resources.title: Generative AI Overview
resources.description: Learn how generative AI models work.

title: Types of AI
subtitle: Narrow AI, general AI, and speculative super AI.
content: AI systems can be classified by capability. Most deployed systems today are narrow AI, built for a single task. General AI aims for human-level flexibility, while super AI is a theoretical concept beyond current research.

tabs.title: Narrow AI
tabs.description: Specialized systems that excel at one task, such as speech recognition or recommendation engines.
bullets: High accuracy in a narrow domain

tabs.title: General AI
tabs.description: A system that can learn any intellectual task. This remains a long-term research goal.

resources.title: Types of Artificial Intelligence
resources.description: Quick overview of AI categories.

title: AI vs ML vs DL
subtitle: Understand how AI, machine learning, and deep learning connect.
content: AI is the umbrella field. Machine learning is a subset focused on learning from data, while deep learning is a subset of ML using multi-layer neural networks. Understanding the hierarchy helps you choose the right tools.

tabs.title: AI vs ML
tabs.description: AI includes rule-based systems and ML models. ML specializes in data-driven learning.
bullets: ML focuses on prediction and patterns

tabs.title: ML vs DL
tabs.description: Deep learning excels on large datasets and unstructured data like images or text.
bullets: DL needs more data and compute
ML can be simpler and faster

resources.title: AI vs ML vs DL
resources.description: Differences between AI, ML, and deep learning.

title: Real-World AI Applications
subtitle: Where AI creates value today.
content: AI is already used in healthcare, finance, e-commerce, and operations. The best use cases combine clear business goals with reliable data pipelines.

tabs.title: Industry Examples
tabs.description: AI supports diagnostics, fraud detection, supply chain forecasting, and personalized recommendations.

tabs.title: Selecting Use Cases
tabs.description: Pick use cases with strong data, measurable impact, and manageable risk.

resources.title: Applications of AI
resources.description: Examples of AI in daily life and industry.

title: Regression and Classification
subtitle: Two core supervised learning tasks.
content: Regression predicts numeric values, while classification assigns labels. Choosing the right approach depends on the output type and business goal.

tabs.title: Regression
tabs.description: Use regression when the outcome is continuous, like price or demand.

tabs.title: Classification
tabs.description: Use classification for categories such as spam vs not spam.

resources.title: Regression vs Classification
resources.description: Compare the two learning tasks.

title: Decision Trees
subtitle: Interpretable models for classification and regression.
content: Decision trees split data based on feature thresholds to reduce impurity. They are simple to interpret and form the basis of random forests and gradient boosting.

tabs.title: How They Work
tabs.description: Trees split data to maximize information gain at each step.
bullets: Choose splits by entropy or Gini

tabs.title: Ensembles
tabs.description: Random forests and gradient boosting combine multiple trees for better accuracy.

resources.title: Decision Tree in ML
resources.description: Decision tree basics with examples.

title: K-Means Clustering
subtitle: Group similar data points without labels.
content: K-Means partitions data into K clusters by iteratively updating cluster centers. It is widely used for segmentation tasks.

tabs.title: Algorithm Steps
tabs.description: Initialize centroids, assign points, update centroids, repeat until convergence.
bullets: Choose K based on elbow method

tabs.title: Use Cases
tabs.description: Use clustering for customer segmentation, anomaly detection, and document grouping.

resources.title: K-Means Clustering
resources.description: Detailed walkthrough and examples.

title: Overfitting and Underfitting
subtitle: Balance bias and variance for reliable models.
content: Overfitting happens when a model memorizes noise. Underfitting happens when the model is too simple. The goal is to generalize well on new data.

tabs.title: Symptoms
tabs.description: Compare training and validation performance to detect problems.

tabs.title: Fixes
tabs.description: Regularization, more data, or simpler models can improve generalization.

resources.title: Bias and Variance
resources.description: Understand the trade-off in ML models.

title: Activation Functions
subtitle: Non-linearities that make deep learning powerful.
content: Activation functions introduce non-linearity. ReLU is common for hidden layers, while sigmoid and softmax are used for probabilistic outputs.

tabs.title: ReLU
tabs.description: ReLU keeps gradients stable and is computationally efficient.
bullets: Use variants like Leaky ReLU if needed

tabs.title: Sigmoid & Softmax
tabs.description: Sigmoid outputs probability for binary tasks, softmax for multi-class tasks.

resources.title: Activation Functions
resources.description: Types of activation functions used in neural networks.

title: Backpropagation
subtitle: How neural networks learn from error signals.
content: Backpropagation computes gradients of the loss with respect to weights. The optimizer then updates weights to reduce error.

tabs.title: Training Flow
tabs.description: Forward pass computes predictions; backward pass propagates gradients.

tabs.title: Tips
tabs.description: Stabilize training with good initialization and normalization.

resources.title: Backpropagation
resources.description: Overview of backpropagation in neural networks.

title: Introduction to Transformers
subtitle: The architecture behind modern language models.
content: Transformers use attention to model relationships between tokens. They scale well and power large language models, translation systems, and summarization.

tabs.title: Attention
tabs.description: Self-attention lets the model focus on relevant tokens across a sequence.

tabs.title: Transformer Blocks
tabs.description: Each block includes attention, feed-forward layers, and residual connections.

resources.title: Transformer Model
resources.description: Overview of transformer architecture.

title: Text Preprocessing
subtitle: Prepare text data for NLP models.
content: Text preprocessing includes tokenization, normalization, and cleaning. Good preprocessing improves model quality and reduces noise.

tabs.title: Steps
tabs.description: Tokenize, lowercase, remove stopwords, and handle punctuation.

tabs.title: Tools
tabs.description: Popular libraries include NLTK, spaCy, and Hugging Face tokenizers.

resources.title: Text Preprocessing in NLP
resources.description: Common NLP preprocessing steps.

title: Sentiment Analysis
subtitle: Measure positive, negative, or neutral text sentiment.
content: Sentiment analysis classifies text by emotion or tone. It is used in product reviews, support analysis, and social media monitoring.

tabs.title: Approaches
tabs.description: Use rule-based lexicons or ML classifiers for sentiment predictions.

tabs.title: Evaluation
tabs.description: Use precision, recall, and confusion matrices to validate results.

resources.title: Sentiment Analysis
resources.description: Definition and techniques in NLP.

title: Language Models
subtitle: Predict text using probability and context.
content: Language models estimate the probability of word sequences. Modern LMs use transformers to model long context and generate fluent text.

tabs.title: Basics
tabs.description: N-grams model short context; transformers handle long-range context.

tabs.title: Use Cases
tabs.description: Language models power chatbots, summarization, and code assistants.

resources.title: Language Models
resources.description: Overview of language modeling.

title: LLM Fundamentals
subtitle: How large language models are trained and used.
content: Large language models are pretrained on huge text corpora and fine-tuned for tasks. They generate outputs token by token using probabilistic sampling.

tabs.title: Training
tabs.description: Pretraining learns general patterns; fine-tuning adapts to specific tasks.

tabs.title: Deployment
tabs.description: Use retrieval augmentation, caching, and guardrails for safe production use.

resources.title: Large Language Models
resources.description: High-level explanation of LLMs.

title: Text-to-Image Models
subtitle: Generate visuals from prompts using diffusion models.
content: Text-to-image models use diffusion or transformer architectures to create images from text prompts. They rely on large datasets of image-caption pairs.

tabs.title: How It Works
tabs.description: Diffusion models start with noise and iteratively denoise to match the prompt.

tabs.title: Prompting
tabs.description: Specific style, subject, and lighting keywords improve outputs.

resources.title: Generative AI
resources.description: Introduction to generative models.

title: AI Agents
subtitle: Systems that plan and take actions to achieve goals.
content: AI agents combine LLM reasoning with tools, memory, and planning. They can execute multi-step workflows like research, scheduling, or code generation.

tabs.title: Components
tabs.description: Agents include a planner, tool use, and memory for context.

tabs.title: Guardrails
tabs.description: Define permissions, scope, and validation steps for safe automation.

resources.title: AI Agents Overview
resources.description: Intro to agent workflows and architectures.

title: Responsible AI Usage
subtitle: Build safe, transparent, and fair AI systems.
content: Responsible AI means designing for fairness, transparency, and user safety. It includes guardrails, human oversight, and clear communication about model limitations.

tabs.title: Safety
tabs.description: Mitigate harmful outputs by adding filters and human review.

tabs.title: Transparency
tabs.description: Explain model behavior and document limitations for users.

resources.title: Ethics in AI
resources.description: Overview of responsible AI principles.
